title: 104_s598
content: The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" raises taxes on cigars and cigarettes. For cigars, the tax rate is increased to $5.8125 per thousand, and for large cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, the tax is 65.875% of the selling price but not exceeding $155 per thousand. The tax rates on cigarettes are amended to $62 per thousand and $130.20 per thousand for different categories. The tax rates on cigarette papers, cigarette tubes, and snuff are amended to 3.875 cents, 7.75 cents, and $62 per thousand respectively. The tax rates on cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco are amended to 7.75 cents, $1.86, 62 cents, and $3.4875 respectively. The excise tax rates on various tobacco products were amended, with changes to rates on chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco, and other products. The amendments apply to products removed after December 31, 1995. The excise tax rates on tobacco products were amended, including a new tax of $1.86 per pound on roll-your-own tobacco manufactured or imported into the United States. The definition of roll-your-own tobacco was also clarified. The definition of roll-your-own tobacco was clarified in the tax code, specifying it as tobacco suitable for making cigarettes. Amendments were made to include roll-your-own tobacco in the excise tax rates on tobacco products. Amendments were made to the tax code to include roll-your-own tobacco in the excise tax rates on tobacco products, along with cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco. Amendments were made to the tax code to include roll-your-own tobacco in the excise tax rates on tobacco products, along with cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco. Chapter 52 regarding tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes was amended in the table of chapters for subtitle E of the Code. The amendments made to Chapter 52 of the tax code regarding tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes apply to roll-your-own tobacco removed after December 31, 1995. A transitional rule allows manufacturers and importers to submit applications before January 1, 1996. The transitional rule allows manufacturers and importers of tobacco products to continue their business pending final action on their application submitted before January 1, 1996. All provisions of Chapter 52 of the tax code apply to the applicant as if they were a permit holder. The transitional rule allows manufacturers and importers of tobacco products to continue their business pending final action on their application. All provisions of Chapter 52 apply to the applicant as if they were a permit holder. Taxes are imposed on various tobacco products held for sale before January 1, 1996. Taxes are imposed on small and large cigars, small and large cigarettes based on weight and price for sale. Taxes are imposed on large cigarettes based on weight and length, with rates varying depending on the size. Taxes are imposed on cigarette papers, tubes, snuff, and chewing tobacco at varying rates based on their size and weight. Taxes are imposed on various tobacco products based on size and weight, with rates for snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco specified. Liabilities and payment methods are outlined for individuals holding these products as of January 1, 1996. Liability for tax on tobacco products imposed by paragraph (1) applies to individuals holding cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco as of January 1, 1996. The tax is due and payable on February 15, 1996, following the same payment method as specified under section 5701 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax on tobacco products is imposed on individuals holding cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco as of January 1, 1996. The tax is due and payable on February 15, 1996, following the same payment method as specified under section 5701 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The terms for these tobacco products are defined in section 5702 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax on tobacco products is imposed on cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco as of January 1, 1996. Retail stocks held on that date are exempt from the tax. Foreign trade zones are also subject to the tax on these tobacco products. Foreign trade zones are exempt from the tax on cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco if entered into the US after January 1, 1996, from a foreign trade zone. Cigars, cigarettes, and other tobacco products are exempt from tax if entered into the US after January 1, 1996, from a foreign trade zone under customs supervision. Cigars, cigarettes, and other tobacco products entering the US from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1996, are subject to tax and treated as held for sale on that date. A trust fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code for this purpose. The establishment of a Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund under SEC. 9512 is outlined in the Internal Revenue Code for tobacco products entering the US from foreign trade zones after January 1, 1996. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, established under SEC. 9512 of the Internal Revenue Code, consists of appropriated amounts and transfers equivalent to 3 percent of revenue increases. The Trust Fund is available for the Secretary of Agriculture to make expenditures for specified purposes. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, established under SEC. 9512 of the Internal Revenue Code, provides assistance to farmers in converting from tobacco to other crops and supports economic diversification plans for communities and persons involved in tobacco production. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund provides assistance to farmers and communities involved in tobacco production to support economic diversification plans. This assistance may include the government purchasing tobacco allotments to retire them from farmers choosing to terminate their involvement in tobacco production. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund supports farmers and communities in transitioning away from tobacco production by purchasing tobacco allotments to retire them.
